bibl.title: Letter from Albert E. Truby to Philip Showalter Hench, August 5, 1943

div1.p: Truby mentions the many complimentary letters about his book. He complains that he was not informed of an upcoming publication of Laura Wood's book on Reed, although he approves it. He reports that two more members of the Yellow Fever Roll of Honor have died.

div1.head: Letter from Albert E. Truby to Philip Showalter Hench, August 5, 1943

opener.dateline:
Albert E. Truby
145 Laurel Street
San Francisco, California
Aug. 5, '43

div1.p:
Becoming an author carries in
its wake a whole lot of letter writing
as I am just now experiencing- In
this connection I want to thank you for the
wonderful telegram you sent me about the
book. Mrs. Truby and I both appreciates
your very complimentary remarks. I have
had nice letters from Mrs. Lazear, Mr. Kellogg,
Gen Kean, Gen. Ireland and others. Even Hosbins
told me how pleased they are to include my book
with their historical publications. My explanations
to them about Laura Wood's book seems to have
been satisfactory and so my mind was relieved
on that score. It had never occured to me
to tell them that she was publishing a book on
Walter Reed. So I have written her a nice
letter, for her book is really a great addition
to the very major literature on Reed's life.
Her work is based on facts, very nicely
written, and shows a vast amount of work on
her part. I still feel, however that she
should have told me before the book came
out that it would soon appear, so that I could
tell Hosbins and prepare them for the “scoop”-

I sent a copy of the book to Dr. Hewitt
at the Mayo Clinic but Laura not heard
from him. I wonder if he is away on
was work also? Dr. Fishbein thanked me
for his copy and said that that a review
would soon appear in the Journal of the A. M. C. O.
I have no idea who will write it, but
no doubt he will select someone competent
to do it properly. I think that you will agree
that it takes someone with a knowledge of the history
of y. f. rather than a literary critic to do
it justice.

I have been too busy to contact Mr Robin
Lampron but will do that, and other things
I promised you, in due time. Am returning
herewith the photo films you loaned me. Thanks.

Two of the y. f. Roll of Honor men have died
recently - Clyde Ford West and England-

Kissinger & his wife are at the State Soldiers Home
in Ind. I sent them a book but I doubt if
Kissinger condition will permit him to get
much and of it.

Tell me some news about yourself, the
baby and your prospects of doing the experiments
on rheumatism you mentioned.
